On Nov 15, 2007, at 11:09 PM, Zack Widup wrote:

>
> I can tell you some of the real story of these two men (much  
> abbreviated
> version).
>
> Nikola Tesla worked for Edison for a while but they had a falling-out
> because Tesla thought of improvements to Edison's inventions that  
> Edison,
> due to ego or whatever, didn't think much of. Tesla also had a  
> habit of
> ordering the most expensive chateaubriand at Edison's expense when  
> Edison
> took him out to dinner. They eventually parted ways.
>
> Tesla happened upon George Westinghouse's lab when Westinghouse needed
> repairs to a motor. Tesla went into the shop and machined such a
> high-quality repair that Westinghouse was immediately impressed. So  
> Tesla
> ended up working for Westinghouse at that point.
>
> Tesla had the idea of developing alternating-current systems for power
> distribution and Westinghouse backed it all the way. AC was much more
> efficient than Edison's DC power distribution systems because it  
> lacked
> the heat losses in the power lines that DC systems suffered from.  
> Edison
> stood to lose much if his DC power systems were discarded in favor  
> of AC
> power. So he invented the electric chair to demonstrate to the public
> just how dangerous AC was. The first attempt at using it on a death- 
> row
> inmate failed miserably; it didn't kill him but amounted to torture
> instead.
>
> Tesla went on to do his own research; much was funded by J. P. Morgan.
> That's a whole 'nother story. But he and Westinghouse remained  
> friends;
> he and Edison remained enemies.
>
> Tesla was a very bad manager of money. He died in a hotel room in New
> York, with very little money at that time.
>
> Another interesting anecdote - Tesla had taken to letting the  
> pigeons into
> his hotel room, which the hotel owners didn't enjoy but tolerated  
> because
> of his notoriety. He had a favorite pigeon which sat on his phone.  
> He had
> said several times that "The day that my favorite pigeon dies, I will
> die." And so it happened.
>
> Zack
>
